p.s: By choosing the right fund to invest your money in , you can have a team of professionals picking stocks , managing your money and executing trades .

Large funds can afford to have a separate person focusing on picking stocks , allocating the assets of the fund into different areas ( stocks , bonds , cash , etc ) and managing the most efficient tax position .
Large funds may also re-invest some of their money into other funds in the pursuit of lower risk and higher gains .
The great thing about mutual funds is that you share the cost of these services with thousands of other investors in the same fund .

list.item:
Research the fund manager 's track record .
Not every fund performs well .
Just because a fund has performed well in the past does n’t necessarily tell you how the fund will perform in the future .
In picking a fund , it helps to research the fund ’s key personnel , their experience and accomplishments , the fees they charge , and their investment style .
Managing other people ’s money requires experience , maturity and a strong sense of responsibility .
Check a fund manager ’s track record .
How well did they do at the last fund they managed ?
While veteran managers ca n't guarantee better performance than a fresh face , there is a lot to be said for experience in the markets .
Having a long view of your manager ’s history will help you to see how they performed in both bull ( strong ) and bear ( weak ) markets .
A consistent performer in both good and bad times is more likely to bring you peace of mind with your investments .
How does a manager 's track record compare to that of his/her peers ?
Be careful with comparisons .
Different managers employ different investing styles .
Some choose growth stocks , ones they expect to grow in value without paying much in dividends .
Others may look for income from dividends .
Still others may choose stocks they believe the market has undervalued .

item.s:
Add “ Alpha ” :
An important measure of a fund manager ’s value is the “ alpha ” that they can add . “ Alpha ” is the measure of how much more the manager adds to the value of your investment than if you had simply invested in an index fund .
An index fund attempts to mirror the market by investing in every company ( or a representative sampling of companies ) listed in a particular index .
Such a list may reflect a particular industry , economic sector , geographic region , company size , or investing style .
You can discover a fund 's " alpha " measurement by researching the fund online at Morningstar.com or various other fund-analysis services .

item.s: Generally index funds charge lower fees , because they face lower research-and-analysis expenses .
They may be expected to do as well as the relevant market in general .
If , on the other hand , you choose to pay the higher fees associated with a managed fund , be sure that the fund manager is not merely following some index .
In regulated financial markets like Europe , UK and Australia , governing bodies publish regular performance figures of the various funds on offer .
These bodies will have information about the key personnel running a fund and may also attempt to define their specific styles .
In the United States there are a number of online sources of such information , notably Morningstar .
